results.title: In the beginning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Celts”.
The first in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This episode asks the questions as to what defines the Celts, both in myth and in genetics. The program opens with discussion of the origins of the Celts in central Europe, far from where they later settled, and examines their distinctive culture and rituals as evidenced in cave drawings, writings of other cultures and archaelogical findings. The tradition of sunworshipping, the movement westward as the weather changed and the gradual move to the iron age is discussed along with the changes in power structures, produce and cultural influences in the Celtic world as trade and thus riches increased. These elements are discussed with reference to archaelogical study while acknowledging the indefinate nature of the history of the Celtic people. The questions that arise as to how they got to Ireland, the area where the contemporary true Celts remain, are investigated with reference to conflicting theories about coastal migration patterns of the time or the ambiguous archaeological evidence which is featured in the area in order to illustrate some possibilities given the difficulty of tracing Celtic history. A study is also recorded in this program of the population in present day Celtic areas and their heritage through a genetic heritage testing project with local school children and a discussion of their family heritage. While the study is seen to shed an interesting light on tracing Celtic history through genetic means it also confirms and engages with the discussion in the rest of the program of the enigma that the Celts remain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: An educational film taking as its starting point “All animals come from the egg”. Depicts with photography and diagrams, ovulation, fertilisation and early cell division of a rabbit embryo. Having depicted a number of scenes of dissection/vivisection, the film concludes with some footage of live animals and a human baby.

results.title: In spite of wishing and wanting
results.creator_credit: Bart Van Langendonck, Ultima Vez, Quasi Modo and Wim Vandekeybus
results.brief_description: Ultima Vez is a dance company formed by director, choreographer, actor and photographer Wim Vandekeybus in 1985. His style is high adrenaline with genuine sense of jeopardy and he draws his dance vocabulary from everyday movement. In creating this piece, Vandekeybus worked in close collaboration with composer David Byrne and with an all-male company. Poetic and passionate, the performance is a powerful and moving mix of movement, music, symbol, words and silence that explores the different tensions, responses, emotions and energy generated by the single-sex cast. This screen adaption of ‘In Spite of Wishing and Wanting’ based on the 1999 dance performance of the same name was shot in the atmospheric surroundings of a racetrack and at the beautiful ballroom-concert hall ‘Vooruit Arts Center’ in Ghent, Belgium. For further information go to http://www.ultimavez.com/

results.title: In space, toward peace
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How can psychology aid astronauts in space? How can psychology end conflict that leads to war? In this program, Philip Zimbardo shows how psychologists can help astronauts battle physical stress, mental stress, anxiety, boredom and depression. He also examines the psychology of peace - the study of the process of dehumanisation in the nuclear arms race and the art of conciliation in negotiating for peace.

results.title: In signal honour: 1865-1965, 100 years of telecommunications
results.brief_description: Produced to celebrate the centenary (1865-1965) of the International Telecommunications Union, this film traces the development of telecommunications during the last hundred years, showing the emergence and impact of telephone, radio, television and apace communications. Highlights include international television transmissions.

results.title: In sickness and in health: women and the health care system
results.creator_credit: John Moore, Open Channel Productions, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Carole Sklan
results.brief_description: Women are the most frequent users of the health care system, but have little say in the way it is run. This program outlines how women can deal with and what they need from the health care system. Includes interviews with sociologists, nurse educators, doctors and patients and is designed to awaken consumer and practitioner awareness of women’s rights in health care.
results.title_for_label: In sickness and in health: women and the health care system

results.title: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq
results.creator_credit: Alex Cohn, Five Rivers Productions and Scott Ritter
results.brief_description: Former United Nations weapons inspector Scott Ritter has compiled this series of interviews and footage into an interesting account of events leading up to the invasion of Iraq. The weapons inspectors were sent in on a supposedly non-political mission, their knowledge base being about weapons. Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.
results.title_for_label: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq
